ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned about disability history, the individual experiences of people with disabilities, and how this applies to relevant debates in education such as inclusion and accessibility, diagnoses, and intersectional identities.

How to record, edit, and create a podcast. Methodologies behind different disability tests. How to advocate to have my learning disabilities accommodated, and how to help others to feel empowered to do the same. Other skills: learned to write and structure a lit review, present on my research, design and write a policy brief.
an understanding of disability and how it fits into education, the questions involved in this issue, and what is being done about it

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: THE PROFESSORS. They are the kindest, most considerate profs you will ever have. They are also receptive to feedback when the reading or workload is too much. They literally go above and beyond in every way. The class teaches practical skills such as reading scientific papers, writing a public policy report, and presenting research, which was nice. 

Weaknesses: Maybe just some extra support for students who do not come from a scientific/psych background earlier in the year!

Strengths - professors really cared about the students and our learning needs, class structure was diverse in mediums of learning (speakers, classmate presentations, videos, discussion of readings) but consistent with expectations, readings assigned were manageable and appropriate. One of the best classes I've taken at Yale because I found myself learning to learn - not to prove myself or meet a deadline. For each class, we could fill out an anonymous feedback form and the profs actually read and responded through action to improve the classroom. The content in this class is also rarely acknowledged or engaged with at Yale. It felt that the class was grounded in a disability justice framework and I improved as a learner and researcher but also as a person and ally.

Weaknesses - need to publish the rubrics sooner (though this was still better/faster than most of my classes). I really appreciated the Modules with instructions & examples of each assignment. It was one of the first syllabi that actually fully made sense to us students!

strengths: super interesting material and assignments
weaknesses: a bit disorganized, sometimes too much discussion

This was a fantastic course with incredibly responsive instructors; they were truly some of the best professors I have ever had at this institution. And they were incredibly knowledgable about all subjects

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I definitely would. It is so important to dedicate time to learning about and internalizing the perspectives of people with disabilities, who are often overlooked, or have their needs assumed for them. It is simply something everyone should be educated about, especially people considering going into fields in education. Ideally, no one should become an educator without taking this course.

Yes. 11/10 class. This class was focused appropriately on major themes and facets of disability studies, while still giving students the opportunity to research and explore topics personally meaningful to us. The workload was manageable and engaging. This class is also important because students aren't trained in disability justice before coming to Yale, despite Yale having a large disabled student population. It was important just to learn about how to better support myself, my peers, and our collective learning needs.
yes!! if you are interested in special education or disability policy
YES! if you have any interest in education, teaching, or psychology, TAKE THIS COURSE
